column1: Konstantin Petrovich Feoktistov (Russian: ?????????? ???????? ??????????; 7 February 1926 21 November 2009) was a Soviet cosmonaut and an eminent space engineer.
Feoktistov also wrote several books on space technology and exploration.
The Feoktistov crater on the Far Side of the Moon is named in his honor.
After being captured by an Waffen-SS Army patrol, Feoktistov was shot by a German officer.
However, the bullet went right through his chin and neck and did not kill him.
Feoktistov was able to crawl out later and then make his way to the Soviet lines.
After the war was over, Feoktistov enrolled in the Bauman Moscow Higher Technical School as an engineering student, and he graduated in 1949.
Feoktistov also later earned a doctorate in physics.
During this time, Feoktistov also worked on a design for an ion-propelled spacecraft to be capable of taking humans to Mars.
During his space flight, he spent just over 24 hours and 17 minutes in space.
After the flight of Voskhod 1, Feoktistov's training for any further space mission was discontinued for medical reasons.

column2: It was a trip that all enjoyed and international friendships were made.

column1: Feoktistov resigned from his engineering position with Energia and then returned to Bauman Moscow Higher Technical School as a professor in 1990.
